name: mailbox
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: letters, mailmen, crying, regret, waiting
text:
i left you five letters

yet, you never replied

gone through four mailmen

for each, i have cried

i let three men take my pen

a mistake i couldn’t erase

you didn’t write for two years

my page had no space

name: hazel
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: colors, eyes, trees, regret, hazel
text:
my favorite colors were brown and green
it reminds me of nature, you know, the trees
but also how natural it is for me to like
your wide hazel eyes.
people love fridays,
but i hate those days
where you become so busy
you come and go. i get dizzy.
my gold in this world is your face,
but i have never won first place.
i sit with wood in my hand
and i attempt to copy and paste.
this sappy sapling of love;
it proves to be too heavy to hold.
now my favorite color is hazel
i write italics, not bold.

name: buzz cut
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: buzz cut, fear, self, change, fall
text:
“be brave, get a buzz cut”
but it has nothing to do 
with me, see 
but, i wanted it to.
my body is round
bound to fall.
saw the clouds;
sound of awe.
there is buzz in my head,
yet it enters one ear.
fear the inside,
my pretty dear.
once i bite into skin,
into the flesh of my mother
shoulder this pain
and fall like a bumble...

name: eighteen
author: cindy nguyen
about: gender, power, growing up, societal expectations
keywords: adulthood, power, safety, women, men, age, control
text:
a teen who wishes they could be older
adults wait for their innocent prey
eighteen, a provoking number
a whistle instead of a “hey”

after eighteen, i lose count of
times i felt unsafe
men who dislike gloves
and things with a bitter taste

yes, we lock our doors to be safe
no, we don’t accuse you guilty
are we if we do it in case
or is your brutality no longer easy

women are the problem
yet, men have most of the power
sure, women can complain
but with a man, they can only cower

stand up, stand up
but we can only reach with heels
and even then we cannot compare
to men who “cannot” feel

when my friend turned eighteen
she physically felt nothing change
but it had always been the first question
strangers asked again and again.

questions a kid asks and
adults avoid: “when you’re older”
but i have yet to understand
why i need a man as a lover

little me wrote in her diary
she said, “when i’m eighteen
i want to live alone”
even i cannot intervene

the realization, born a woman
from a woman, you live alone
regardless of your decisions
it's simply the debt women owe.

name: saving
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: saving, time, memories, marriage, love
text:
i don’t need saving
whether it be an account
or my kindergarten painting.

life lessons she gave me:
“save the best for last”
i whisper “quickly”
they suggest i save myself for marriage
for a man who only loves
in the back of a modern carriage.

save your breath
for when you witness me cry
out, what a mess
there are pictures i save
memories and moments i will lose
yet i print it out hoping it will stay

you cannot save the ticking time
when you don’t know how much you have
pretty things tend to always die

name: storm
author: cindy nguyen
about: parental warnings, growing up, loss, childhood
keywords: sharks, sun, sand, water, swimming, motherhood
text:
as if only poison floats

to the shores of florida

my mother warns of sharks

but not of the sun, a

cloud gets noticed

only when it rains

only when’s it’s gray

only when it begs

please don’t run away

sand flies into the air

like i try to escape

but it tugs at my hair

causing a throbbing pain.

mother treads quietly on sand

but she throws it like glass

and it hurts like a hand.

mother warned of the depth of the water

yet never taught me how to swim

or how to hold my breath longer.

mother, swim fast to save a flailing child,

mother is too old

instead she says

i told you so.

name: again
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: time, hourglass, memory, love, loss, friendship
text:
i give you all my time like 

how an hourglass pours

you come and go like 

i’m a revolving door

i stuff memories in

a small clutch bag

i’ve lost memories ever since

my takeout became bad

unspoken aggression scratches

it irritates my skin

similar to how my thighs chafe

or how you and me have been

i hope my favorite people

turn into strangers

i will love again, i hope

you’ll choose me to be friends with

name: desperation
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: child, mother, death, lies, desperation, cliff, breath
text:
a child who cries
for their mother
the lies told white
to a brother
grasp of a cliff
gasp of my breath
pleading the fifth
sight-seeing death
all desperate
the words i say
seem separate
from a pale face

name: willow
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: trees, waiting, love, growth, dandelion, willow, friendship
text:
talking to a wall
but the wood is alive.
my chest like heavy stone,
climbing stairs to reach your eye.

i wished on willow trees,
but you swayed like dandelion,
fluff hair and hazel green,
the only friend i'd lie with.

this sapling of warmth,
a gift of steady growth,
i can wait years more:
"in our late thirties," i wrote.

name: night lover
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: shyness, dance, firelight, moon, stars, opposites attract, desire
text:
moments wasted being shy,
but i treasure a glance,
you in the corner of my eye,
and your silly little dance.

magnetic pull of hand
because opposites attract
the line of your tan
matches the line of my sight.

the heat of the fire
illuminates our skin
as it rises higher and higher,
exposing my admiration.

if i was the moon
and you were the sky,
i'd be a lovesick fool
following your stars at night.

name: seasick
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: sea, sickness, memory, fog, ocean, loss, sunscreen, sea glass
text:
i don't miss the ocean
or the breeze against my skin.
i don't miss the sunscreen lotion
or the "how have you been?"

i feel "sea" sick
but i'm not sick of the sea.
my stomach is turning
like it has somewhere to be.

already sick at sea
and i don't know what to do
when the fog is so thick
i cannot see you.

like high tide under blue sky
sandals and shorts
seashells pretty to the eye
and boats along ports.

i'm washed up next to
sea glass and a quarter,
reminders of you
when i am seasick by the water.

name: blush
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: blush, pink, skin, contrast, love, smile, irritation
text:
heat rises to my face
matching yours:
a coral flush.
deep pinks, soft pinks,
a pinch of skin,
playful irritation.

void of color,
my skin: pale
to give up/ to fail,
your natural blush
and toothy grin
loving, smiling.

name: outline
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: outline, fading, crying, drift, memory, display, glasses, separation
text:
somehow i recall your face

love truly does exist

empty; an outline of praise

my glasses broke last spring

after summer, i missed

your shell left lingering

residing elsewhere

i cry out as we drift

a parting i can’t bear

now, i stand in a display

watching you walk by

as your outline fades away.

name: unspoken
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: brows, tremble, silence, white lie, glance, unspoken, longing
text:
i ignore the furrow of your brows

like how you ignore the tremble of my hand

i look up, but on me, you look down

and again, you turn this page

i had hoped to see you smile

a little longer, towards me

i see instead your white lie

an unspoken plea

name: finger prints
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: rain, crime, love, goodbye, fingerprints, cold, gloves, memory
text:
a rainfall like hot oil

i remember sometime(s)

last year, you said

loving is not a crime

i recall words like they are 

laws: “i promise”, “never”

to leave

goodbyes in a letter

if i were to be found

they’d find fingerprints

under my blouse

scattered like lint

criminals wear gloves

strangers wear none

i saw your kissed skin 

yet you felt cold like bone

yesterday, i looked for

you, like me

and you hate each

conversation i seek

name: enough
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: detachment, love, mind, body, eyes, fire, tangle, enough
text:
i found myself wondering if i would ever be enough,

detached from my body, i

who had never experienced love,

watched my mind ablaze from fire.

days i spend under the shelter of

detachment from your eyes 

a tangle in my hair brush

and the way my eyes shut tight.

name: exhaustion
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: exhaustion, character, sickness, waiting, sleep, identity, emptiness
text:
i have never felt exhaustion like this

my tingling numb made new friends

an ache stomps in my chest

wandering thoughts with no dead-end

last night i hugged myself

afraid i’d lose who i saw

in sickness and in health

someone i could call

today i watch my character sit idle 

like a child waiting to be picked

she is me and i am her smile

yet i cannot find me within

i sleep for tomorrow, yet again

it creeps into my unconscious state

empty outlines of strangers (friends)

when awake, i realize i’m too late.

name: static
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: stairs, running, breath, emotion, stillness, fear, distance
text:
i’ve climbed stairs taller than floor five

people below look smaller than those on nine

eye-contact both intrigues yet terrifies

i’ll tremble as another emotion dies

i hate the way running makes me breathe

desperation for air has made everyone leave

in a way, we will always be the same

me still and static you became

name: dear sky
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: moon, star, cloud, apology, self-doubt, silence, beauty, longing
text:
dear moon,

i watched you shine like a mother watches her child

besides mine, because her touch feels like sun.

who am i to judge the beauty of your shape

when i cannot see my own with clothes undone.

dear star,

i begin with the same never-ending apologies.

constellations convinced me you could never feel alone.

silence with you feels as if we’re no longer alive,

now i miss you like i lack a backbone.

dear cloud,

you remind me of an exhausted sister.

they hate your grey hue but curse you

when the weight becomes too much.

i know it is the sun you pursue.

name: stranger
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: stranger, silence, comfort, danger, heart, fear
text:
to strangers again,

unfamiliar conversation:

the start of the end

your eyes were peering

i felt my heart plop, see

it lays and beats quietly.

silence has become a stranger

and comfort no longer lingers

i fear it more than danger

name: purple
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: violet, color, name, self-identity, ocean tide, note, relationships
text:
i met a girl named violet.

most girls wore dresses,

but she wore a black turtleneck.

i asked about her favorite color,

curious if she liked her own name

or if it was forced upon her.

she said she loved violet, but 

she’d rather be a pretty lavender.

her face soured like bitter plum.

violet’s favorite color:

bright purple, supposedly

her mother had told her.

violet pulled me aside

and whispered into my ear.

she adored the color of ocean tide.

violet handed me a purple note

asking me what my favorite color was,

you can guess what i wrote.

name: release
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: freedom, tears, hug, letting go, pain, brokenness, knees
text:
i felt freedom clutch at my lungs

as a small girl cried into my shoulder

her tears held heat like acid

mine grew rancid becoming older

yesterday you said to let go

yet tissue became my sleeve

she cries so miserably broken

i hug her like i do my knees

name: stings
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: bees, sting, numbness, pain, mother, attachment, body, wounds, fear
text:
when did i become so familiar

sitting in the puncture of my wound

with the dull pain of a sting

held still like a permanent tattoo

i’ve grown attached to temporary

or maybe i am numb to my muscle

when they left, it stung

but i’ve felt far more miserable.

maybe i chase bees because 

i too fear stinging another

at the cost of my humanity

afraid of my mother

i’ve felt my knees become weak

i’ve felt, or rather didnt, my body

become numb until the ground 

scraped my hands sorry

name: click
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: halves, romance, comedy, movies, hope, time, emptiness, breakup, alone
text:
i wanted us to be 

halves that clicked

ever so naturally

like a romance flick

instead like comedy

humor to cope

replaying scenes

that gave me hope

in movies we watched

lack of love and

pictures i want instead 

an empty hand

a tick of the clock

hourglass flipped

no click, no knock

our halves missed

throwing up

again: we know

we lose us

again: alone

name: pages
author: cindy nguyen
about: love, memory, regret, fiction vs. reality
keywords: books, romance, memory, names, regret, thrill, reading, fiction, love
text:
the books i read are romance

as if love will forever be fiction

many have asked me to dance

i have yet to hear their diction

i wonder if i skipped a few

unable to recall his name

how did i end up on

the pain of this page

constant warnings to read slow

but i get caught in the thrill

the slap of wind on a boat

a book of memories i must fill

name: iridescent
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: color, light, memory, reflection, emotion, mother, iridescence, love, presence
text:
from here, i can see your color

one step forward and you change

it reminds me of my mother

like a jeweled ring on a hand

you’re familiar like a memory

the reflections i’ve made and seen

i remember the pain of an injury

and the shrill of an angry scream

your heart is beautifully iridescent

i’ve seen you blue, red, and green

you give your light like a present

i hope you feel loved and seen

name: flight
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: flight, florida, sun, journey, wallet, id, coins, memory, loss, yearning
text:
i flew from south last july
only florida's sun's seen my skin
you'll know when you try
to fly is to reach my end

destination is simply a place
i've heard to value the journey
in-between these lines: this space
i recognize i'm yearning

change since i lost my cash
my pocket has holes i can't find
the plane will push me back
but flies back to home each time

monday morning i check my wallet
of course there is my id
but inside along my coins
a carved coin from sightseeing

name: height
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: jumping, fear, society, flowers, grounding, sky, height, spring, rebirth
text:
when you asked if i would jump

i wonder how high you imagined me

society has shared it like a stick of gum

and chewed it as if they got it for free

i’ve felt fear like she was my lover

she’s made me shake uncontrollably

i’ve asked, screamed, and begged her

for who we could’ve been and couldn’t be

the flowers received cling to my collar

if i lift myself from the ground

words wrapped around my core turn

to keep me rooted and ripped down

i discussed with the sky my fear of height

desire the rush and fall to feel a high

jumping to conclusions and into fights

just for spring to bring me back to life

name: letters
author: cindy nguyen
about: estrangement, grief, writing, maternal relationships, emotional pain
keywords: letters, apology, mother, loss, grief, love, writing, chapters, salt water
text:
what sits in my hand is a letter of apology

to someone who thought i was undeserving of

a single word of leaving, like i was

undeserving of love

what lays on the floor is a letter of grievance

for someone who is alive and breathing

our worlds coexist but we cannot

live like me: an apparent heathen

if one’s life flashes before their eyes

then i have died too many times

the proof is in the letters:

the letters i continue to write

i write, “dear mother”

a page turns into chapters

the content reeks of salt water: shore 

i’ll reach the page’s end faster

name: bear
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: bear, primal urge, praise, tangible, show, eyes, surprise
text:
bear with me, please

i was passed, not raised

watching others be taught

watching others be praised

you beg me of primal urge

but i have no desire to sleep

what awaits is a mother bear

who cannot bear with me

i do not crave for fish

unable to feel for an animal 

able to live where they swim

whereas i am barely tangible

they boast of my ability

i exist for show to closed eyes

it is only when they look

the skills i do not bear surprise

name: november
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: sun, green, tears, love, books, moon, crescent, decision, mother, rain, comfort, november
text:
sun leaves faster than the color

deep green, grey days

remind me of tears i’ve shed

over the lack of love i praise

a body that sits beside unopened

books that discuss the fall, you

recall the hug of a friend

like the warmth from moon

crescents are eyes which cry

from the loss of decision’s effect

which have wrenched the heart

mother failed to protect

the days providing rain

come and go like a comfort

to the november who struggles

to hug a friend who hurts.

name: forget it
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: memory, suicide, phone, tears, dead eyes, silence, forgive, violence
text:
i recall a memory like it’s a suicidal friend

‘pick up the phone’ with tears in my eyes

scared to wake up my friend?

those are dead eyes.

empty words like ‘forget it’

all i’ve heard is the eery silence

forgive me, i daydream

head in hand with violence

name: empty room
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: moon, crescent, lie, sentiments, empty room, suspense, waiting, home
text:
moon peeks through window

like crescent eyes; you hide behind

a lie; i let you tell me many

sweet sentiments sometimes

i lay in bed tonight,

the same empty room,

and yet, you’re by my side

whispering “soon”

never felt suspense so deep

in me, you will find

a girl waiting for her home

hoping you’ll take her inside

name: clock
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: tick, suspense, object permanence, nervousness, clock, radio static, struggle, talk
text:
when the time goes tick tick

ticklish feeling in my nose

the sound of the stick

suspense for the come and goes

object permanence

out of sight

such nervousness

not out of mind

breathing to match

the third hand of the clock

radio static scratch

a struggle to talk

name: anemone
author: cindy nguyen
keywords: protection, dust, goodbyes, sorrow, anemone, vines, shame, darkness, sunlight, love, flowers
text:
she watches who she stands over evaporate

her job to protect what she's loved failed

in her hands, dust

her eyes are lost to the pity sailed


they go with tears in their eyes

the waves of goodbyes are never-ending

how sorrow her cries

oh anemone protect me against ill


she tears the vines that reach to her

she ravages in shame

scratch marks against her wrist

tears stain her name again


she calls anemone her guardian

she also calls it her darkness

her attempts to end it are futile

in her heart she sought this


sunlight warmth

all that is needed to smile

because days that are cold

means you'll disappear for a while.


may you be the flower that grew from love

instead of the vines that grew from dislike

may you love her the way she only can dream of

till it's no longer you she waters.

name: While I Wash My Face I Ask Impossible Questions of Myself and Those Who Love Me
author: Charif Shanahan
keywords: mirror, dust, new beginnings, function, wings, fins, focus, meaning, questions
text:
Specks of toothpaste fleck the mirror.

A fan spins dust in the hall.

I find “this is it” too vulgar to accept

So I wait for a new starting point

As though life will begin there and then.

Do you know what I mean?

Not what I’m saying, what I mean.

Is it possible my function is to hold

All the intricate, interstitial pain

And articulate clarity?

Tie a boat to my wrist, I sprout wings.

Give me a pair of shoes, I grow fins.

Twice an hour I trick myself into focus:

I look into the glass as I look through it.

When the new beginning comes, what then?

Does life suddenly reset like an Atari?

Does meaning emerge

Assertively and without invitation?

The task is to live well enough with you.

But how? How do you know what you want

If you don’t tell you? If you don’t hear you?

name: Ozymandias
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
keywords: ruins, power, time, sculpture, desert
text:
I met a traveller from an antique land,
Who said—“Two vast and trunkless legs of stone
Stand in the desert. . . . Near them, on the sand,
Half sunk a shattered visage lies, whose frown,
And wrinkled lip, and sneer of cold command,
Tell that its sculptor well those passions read
Which yet survive, stamped on these lifeless things,
The hand that mocked them, and the heart that fed;
And on the pedestal these words appear:
‘My name is Ozymandias, king of kings;
Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair!’
Nothing beside remains. Round the decay
Of that colossal Wreck, boundless and bare
The lone and level sands stretch far away.”

name: The Raven
author: Edgar Allan Poe
keywords: raven, loss, mourning, midnight, nevermore
text:
Once upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered, weak and weary,
Over many a quaint and curious volume of forgotten lore—
While I nodded, nearly napping, suddenly there came a tapping,
As of some one gently rapping, rapping at my chamber door—
"'Tis some visitor," I muttered, "tapping at my chamber door—
Only this and nothing more."
Once upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered, weak and weary,
Over many a quaint and curious volume of forgotten lore—
While I nodded, nearly napping, suddenly there came a tapping,
As of some one gently rapping, rapping at my chamber door—
"'Tis some visitor," I muttered, "tapping at my chamber door—
Only this and nothing more."

name: Forgetfulness
author: Billy Collins
keywords: memory, forgetting, aging, muses, novels
text:
The name of the author is the first to go
followed obediently by the title, the plot,
the heartbreaking conclusion, the entire novel
which suddenly becomes one you have never read, never even heard of,
as if, one by one, the memories you used to harbor
decided to retire to the southern hemisphere of the brain,
to a little fishing village where there are no phones.
Long ago you kissed the names of the nine muses goodbye

name: When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom'd
author: Walt Whitman
keywords: Lincoln, lilacs, death, mourning, bird
text:
When lilacs last in the dooryard bloom’d,
And the great star early droop’d in the western sky in the night,
I mourn’d, and yet shall mourn with ever-returning spring.
Ever-returning spring, trinity sure to me you bring,
Lilac blooming perennial and drooping star in the west,
And thought of him I love.

name: Sonnet 18 ("Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?")
author: William Shakespeare
keywords: summer, beauty, time, poetry, eternity
text:
Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?
Thou art more lovely and more temperate:
Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May,
And summer’s lease hath all too short a date;
Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines,
And often is his gold complexion dimm’d;
And every fair from fair sometime declines,
By chance or nature’s changing course untrimm’d;
But thy eternal summer shall not fade,
Nor lose possession of that fair thou ow’st;
Nor shall Death brag thou wander’st in his shade,
When in eternal lines to time thou grow’st:
So long as men can breathe or eyes can see,
So long lives this, and this gives life to thee.

name: Mankindness
author: Christina Davis
keywords: battle, love, relationships, understanding
text:
1

Because he, because she,
in so far as
she (in so far as he) exists

is on the way
to battle.

Not what is your name,
but what
the battle?




2

“Each one of us has come
here and changed” —

is the battle. Born
a loved one,
borne a loved one.




3

My father fought in this war, thus I can speak of it.
My mother fought in this, thus I can speak.
My friends, my lovers have fought, have worn
(like the tree) their several directions at once. And I,

in so far as I
               can say “I”

have fought to be related to these —
we strive and strain
but also try to ripen the entity
of the Other.





4

We kiss on lips, where the tenses attach.

We enter the conundrum
of another’s becoming.

We look for someone who can raise us
up again to feet, or near to standing.

We tend in our terrors to forget (we
do not store them) felicities.

I try each day to stay near beings,
mornings when I am most
mild. And may I nothing harm,
in case it is them.

name: The Poem You’ve Been Waiting For
author: Tarfia Faizullah
keywords: waiting, love, journey, self-discovery
text:
I saw then the white-eyed man
leaning in to see if I was ready

yet to go where he has been waiting
to take me. I saw then the gnawing

sounds my faith has been making
and I saw too that the shape it sings

in is the color of cast-iron mountains
I drove so long to find I forgot I had

been looking for them, for the you
I once knew and the you that was born

waiting for me to find you. I have been
twisting and turning across these lifetimes

where forgetting me is what you do
so you don’t have to look at yourself. I saw

that I would drown in a creek carved out
of a field our incarnations forged the first path

through to those mountains. I invited you to stroll
with me there again for the first time, to pause

and sprawl in the grass while I read to you
the poem you hadn’t known you’d been waiting

to hear. I read until you finally slept
and all your jagged syntaxes softened into rest.

You’re always driving so far from me towards
the me I worry, without you, is eternity. I lay there,

awake, keeping watch while you snored.
I waited, as I always seem to, for you

to wake up and come back to me.

name: Here
author: Dorothy Randall Gray
keywords: waiting, longing, connection, hope
text:
Here among the neophytes and the nephilim
The believers and betrayers nuns and naysayers
Among affirmations of time and no time
            With voices seen and nameless love
            Where angels cry and questions wait
            Where stars speak   waters sing   and earth ceases its spin

Here is where I wait for you
            Will you come in the dark without knowing
            Will you come with the wind brushing my hair
            Will you hum like giraffes in the night
            Will you come late with excuses   or early with whispers

Here is where I wait for you
            Will you be the dream never dreamed
            Will you come with what I need to hear
            Will you come with bells and bones, oceans and orishas
            Will you want me as I am   pretend my lips are yours
            Will you make the sun smile, the night jealous, the moon go mad

Here is where I wait for you
            Will I know your name
            Will the air close its fists tight around us
            Will you come with flowers or forests
            Will you bring all the pieces of you
            Will your brilliance hurt my eyes
            Will you walk with thunder, kiss me like rain
            Will you be the end of my beginnings   name the moments I’ve lost
            Will you come soft as baby’s breath, cotton picked by grandma’s hands,
                        like her skin before she died
            Will you come like barefoot fields and full bellies
            Will you come before I forget who I am,
                        before the last call, the first light of day
            Will you look for me or look like heaven
            Will you find me working late, working words,
                        or working like I’m worth it

Here is where I wait for you
            Will you come with expectations
            Will you come without guile, without words or language to understand
            Will you come soon ... or not at all

name: From “Hymn”
author: Staceyann Chin
keywords: faith, identity, transformation, longing
text:
Song in secret, Song of  spite and
spirit, Song in the temple, temple of Song
and perpetual farewell. Sudden, O
Song, fallen on me as a passing wind,
naming as the wind names—absence, farewell.

O Shadow Song, whose hill is green and leaving,
right my walk in glory, begin.

When the trees were leafless, I put my voice,
O Tenuous Air, among the barren places, among even the
nothingness of frost. Thinking I knew myself. O Fortifier,
O Hidden-in-the-weeds, going green. A green concert, hollow green.

O Ship, your going on without me is my résumé entire.
Thy keel floats on, O Possibility. If  I anchor as you.
If I set my anchor here. If I can hum through.
The necessary masterpiece. If I can respond in kind
to the loneliness of Wyeth’s Grape Wine, recognizing, turning the corner
in the great museum, that I am the drifter, O River,
with his back turned to his fashioner.


 

How long had I suffered, white-knuckled, anchored to my name, wanting clearly to walk to wide avenues wearing ornate buttons, wishing to be loved by the god of syntax. Had gone mad and gone, tonguing out my name. This nothingness, I’d proved it upon my pulse. Realized the self was daily. One moment into the next, as turning the corner I expect everyone I’ve known to appear with my other name, a coin in the mouth, a rotten tooth. As if I’m nothing when not regarded, as light is, as is the ancient tongue buried below perceivable language, its many tessellations into sound. I want to be called as you call yourself, I say to the unfolding blooms. How they hold perfection and not announce. Do not announce on the wide avenues, the mountain’s grandeur. The bloom takes part in the mountain. The mountain is my true lover who, before the road, humbles me when I set out trying to know. To understand what is below knowing. Love the mountain. Whose blue face I rise toward, who does not betray, who is mist-clothed, whose water I gather as breathing. Who has been one tree. Who has been a seed. Who stills itself in battle. Who cannot ask, “if then thou gavest.” Whose oath to the bloom is unreachable. O Joiner, let me among that private communion. Let me be all as if I had all.



Release me, O Redeemer, from the tyranny of my desire
for that which has been weighed against, has killed my people.

Place in my path, O Architect,
the bitter green medicine that reaches for me,

that leans as I do towards the sun,
that huddles together as my people in praise of you,

your name—a sharp taste in my mouth, a righteous sound
I can lean against. O Transformer, whose blessings multiply
before me as yarrow by the train tracks. I trust in

the givenness of things. I trust in the wind and the ache in my knee.
For it is thy hum at my center, O Witness, that breathes me.

name: Poem for the Black Bird
author: Alina Stefanescu
keywords: memory, family, identity, longing, heritage
text:
Today I wept with the kids as we drove
the dirt roads, grass greener than ever. I felt it
closed. The meadows smothered dozing cows in clover
and violet. A certain valence. It came so close
to something nameless. I needed the omnivorous
metaphor, a golden omen. I needed to touch
its extreme beak with my mind, to know
it existed. That afternoon decades ago
when my mom went to Wal-Mart, the red poppies
ran across her skirt, her eyes bluer than melting glaciers.
She emerged with a bag, no explanation. And I drove
us back to the house my dad won by divorcing.
I don’t remember how night descended, whether feathered
or furred, no poem-bird could hold it. Mom went inside
first. I stood near the pine and lied to love, lied to its face. I felt it
closed. And there was Mom, in the window,
unwrapping her purchase. She set a chair near the socket,
plugged in her pen. I watched her blaze the pine-panel walls
with a wood-burner. It wound round the rim of the room
and grew rounder, the part I didn’t see coming.
You will never forget me, Doru. No one else left
their homeland for you. Her hands shook, pressing
words into the flesh of our home. The life she was
leaving. Her notes, that winding charred necklace,
encircling us. The bird was not black.
It was the color of fire absent smoke.
I can’t forget what it spoke.

name: For My Friend
author: Eileen Myles
keywords: friendship, daily life, reflection, longing, memory
text:
Nothing
better
for people
than dogs
nothing better than ma
king
you scream
here. There were
two super
new cars
and then
some pink
chicken
filets
I guess
there were
berries
for sale
in Scandinavia
a man in
a plaid
shirt &
cookies
also they
are
working
in the ceme
tery
I can see
their blue
ladder
from here.
A man
has written
a book
about many
deaths
or many
things to do after.
Read it
read it
they say
but what
comes
after
is a small
idea. Now
is large
rainy.
Amy I wish
you luck

name: Katrina
author: Patricia Smith
keywords: Hurricane Katrina, destruction, personification, storm
text:
I was birthed restless and elsewhere
 
gut dragging and bulging with ball lightning, slush,
broke through with branches, steel
 
I was bitch-monikered, hipped, I hefted
a whip rain, a swirling sheet of grit.
 
Scraping toward the first of you, hungering for wood, walls,
unturned skin. With shifting and frantic mouth, I loudly loved
the slow bones
 
of elders, fools, and willows.

name: Prologue—And Then She Owns You
author: Patricia Smith
keywords: personification, seduction, danger, allure
text:
This is not morning. There is a nastiness
slowing your shoes, something you shouldn’t step in.
It’s shattered beads, stomped flowers, vomit—
such stupid beauty,
 
beauty you can stick a manicured finger
into and through, beauty that doesn’t rely
on any sentence the sun chants, it’s whiskey
swelter blown scarlet.
 
Call this something else. Last night it had a name,
a name wedged between an organ’s teeth, a name
pumping a virgin unawares, a curse word.
Wail it, regardless,
 
Weak light, bleakly triumphant, will unveil scabs,
snippets of filth music, cars on collapsed veins.
The whole of gray doubt slithers on solemn skin.
Call her New Orleans.
 
Each day she wavers, not knowing how long she
can stomach the introduction of needles,
the brash, boozed warbling of bums with neon crowns,
necklaces raining.
 
She tries on her voice, which sounds like cigarettes,
pubic sweat, brown spittle lining a sax bell
the broken heel on a drag queen’s scarlet slings.
Your kind of singing.
 
Weirdly in love, you rhumba her edges, drink
fuming concoctions, lick your lukewarm breakfast
directly from her crust. Go on, admit it.
You are addicted
 
to her brick hips, the thick swerve she elicits,
the way she kisses you, her lies wide open.
She prefers alleys, crevices, basement floors.
Hell, let her woo you.
 
This kind of romance dims the worth of soldiers,
bends and breaks the back, sips manna from muscle,
tells you Leave your life. Pack your little suitcase,
flee what is rigid
 
and duly prescribed. Let her touch that raw space
between cock and calm, the place that scripts such jazz.
Let her pen letters addressed to your asking.
You s-s-stutter.
 
New Orleans’s, p-please. Don’t. Blue is the color
stunning your tongue. At least the city pretends
to remember to be listening.
She grins with glint tooth,
 
wiping your mind blind of the wife, the children,
the numb ritual of job and garden plot.
Gently, she leads you out into the darkness
and makes you drink rain.

name: Undertaker
author: Patricia Smith
keywords: mourning, death, funeral, motherhood, loss
text:
When a bullet enters the brain, the head explodes.
I can think of no softer warning for the mothers
who sit doubled before my desk,
knotting their smooth brown hands, 
and begging, fix my boy, fix my boy.
Here's his high school picture.
And the smirking, mildly mustachioed player
in the crinkled snapshot
looks nothing like the plastic bag of boy
stored and dated in the cold room downstairs. 
In the picture, he is cocky and chiseled,
clutching the world by the balls. I know the  look. 
Now he is flaps of cheek, 
slivers of jawbone, a surprised eye,
assorted teeth, bloody tufts of napped hair.
The building blocks of my business.

So I swallow hard, turn the photo face down
and talk numbers instead. The high price
of miracles startles the still-young woman,
but she is prepared. I know that she has sold
everything she owns, that cousins and uncles
have emptied their empty bank accounts,
that she dreams of her baby 
in tuxedoed satin, flawless in an open casket,
a cross or blood red rose tacked to his fingers,
his halo set at a cocky angle.
I write a figure on a piece of paper
and push it across to her
while her chest heaves with hoping. 
She stares at the number, pulls in
a slow weepy breath: "Jesus."

But Jesus isn't on this payroll. I work alone
until the dim insistence of morning, 
bent over my grisly puzzle pieces, gluing,
stitching, creating a chin with a brushstroke. 
I plop glass eyes into rigid sockets,
then carve eyelids from a forearm, an inner thigh.
I plump shattered skulls, and paint the skin
to suggest warmth, an impending breath.
I reach into collapsed cavities to rescue
a tongue, an ear. Lips are never easy to recreate. 

And I try not to remember the stories, 
the tales the mothers must bring me
to ease their own hearts. Oh, they cry, 
my Ronnie, my Willie, my Michael, my Chico.
It was self-defense. He was on his way home, 
a dark car slowed down, they must have thought
he was someone else. He stepped between
two warring gang members at a party.
Really, he was trying to get off the streets, 
trying to pull away from the crowd. 
He was just trying to help a friend. 
He was in the wrong place at the wrong time. 
​​​​​​​Fix my boy; he was a good boy. Make him the way he was.

​​​​​​​But I have explored the jagged gaps
in the boy's body, smoothed the angry edges
of bulletholes. I have touched in in places
no mother knows, and I have birthed
his new face. I know he believed himself
invincible, that he most likely hissed
"Fuck you, man" before the bullets lifted him
off his feet. I try not to imagine
his swagger, his lizard-lidded gaze,
his young mother screaming into the phone.

She says she will find the money, and I know
this is the truth that fuels her, forces her
to place one foot in front of the other. 
Suddenly, I want to take her down
to the chilly room, open the bag
and shake its terrible bounty onto the 
gleaming steel table. I want her to see him, 
to touch him, to press her lips to the flap of cheek.
The woman needs to wither, finally, and move on. 

We both jump as the phone rattles in its hook. 
I pray it's my wife, a bill collector, a wrong number.
But the wide, questioning silence on the other end
is too familiar. Another mother needing a miracle. 
​​​​​​​Another homeboy coming home.
